container.heading: Sports Wagering Licensee Minimum Internal Control Standards

para.text: Definition. Unless context or the individual regulation dictates otherwise, for purposes of this chapter, “sports wagering licensee” includes:
Sports wagering facility licensee;
Mobile sports wagering licensee;
Sports wagering facility operator licensee; and
Online sports wagering operator licensee.
A sports wagering licensee shall maintain complete, accurate, and legible records of all transactions pertaining to the revenues and expenses of sports wagering operations.
General ledger records shall be maintained on a double entry system of accounting with transactions recorded on a basis consistent with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.
Subsidiary ledgers and records supporting general ledger records shall be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.
Subsidiary ledgers and records shall include, at a minimum, documents that:
Support the financial statements and all transactions impacting the financial statements including contracts or agreements with sports wagering contractors;
Identify all sports wagering activity on a week-to-date, month-to-date, and year-to-date basis for the following:
Handle;
Payout;
Win amount;
Win percentage; and
Average payout percentage;
Summarize the cost, by category of service, of complimentary services under Regulation .08 of this chapter;
Identify all costs and expenses associated with the sports wagering operation;
Are prepared in compliance with the internal controls approved by the Commission under Regulation .04 of this chapter; and
Relate to:
Loans and other amounts payable by a sports wagering licensee;
Bettor disputes including bettor complaint forms filed with the Commission under Regulation .37 of this chapter;
Negotiable instruments accepted, deposited, returned as uncollected or ultimately written-off by a sports wagering licensee under this chapter; and
Investments in property and equipment for the benefit of a sports wagering licensee.
A form or document required by this chapter, including stored data, shall have:
All information placed on the form or document recorded in ink or another permanent form; and
The title of the form or document and the name of the sports wagering licensee imprinted or preprinted on it.

If under this chapter multiple copies are required of a form or document, all copies shall have the name of the intended recipient of the copy preprinted on the bottom of the copy in order to differentiate between the copies.

If under this chapter a form or document is required to be accounted for by series number or copies of a form or document are required to be compared for agreement, the accounting department shall report exceptions in writing to the responsible department and sports wagering licensees’ internal audit department not later than 2 days after identification of the exception.
A sports wagering licensee may prepare more copies of a form or document than required by this chapter.
At least 60 days prior to commencing sports wagering and any time a change is made thereafter, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for approval internal controls for:
Sports wagering at the sports wagering licensee’s facility; or
Online sports wagering.
Each procedure or control submission shall, at a minimum, include both narrative and diagrammatic representations of the system to be utilized including the following:
Administrative controls and record keeping that document the authorization of transactions;
Accounting controls that provide reasonable assurance that:
Transactions or financial events which occur in connection with the sports wagering operation are:
Executed in accordance with the sports wagering licensee’s authorization protocols;
Recorded to permit preparation of financial statements in conformance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States and the requirements of this chapter; and
Recorded to permit proper and timely reporting and calculation of proceeds and to maintain accountability for assets;
Access to assets is permitted only in accordance with the sports wagering licensee’s authorization protocols; and
The recorded accountability for assets is compared with existing assets at reasonable intervals and appropriate action is taken with regard to a discrepancy;
User access controls for all personnel;
Procedures and controls for ensuring:
That systems accurately and timely communicate all required activities and financial details to the sports wagering platform;
That all functions, duties, and responsibilities are segregated and performed in accordance with sound financial practices by qualified personnel; and

Through the use of a surveillance and a security department, that the sports wagering licensee is secure at all times during normal operation and during any emergency due to malfunctioning equipment, loss of power, natural disaster, or any other cause;
An organizational chart depicting appropriate functions and responsibilities of employees involved in sports wagering;
A description of the duties and responsibilities of each position shown on the organizational chart;
Access controls which address, at a minimum:
Content of, and administrative responsibility over, the manual or computerized access control matrix governing employee access to restricted areas;
Issuance of a temporary access credential; and
Comprehensive key controls;
Procedures and controls over the movement of cash and the count room;
Procedures and standards for conducting internal audits;
The record retention policy;
Procedures to be utilized by the sports wagering licensee to prevent an individual younger than 21 years old, an excluded individual, and bettors outside the State from engaging in sports wagering;
Procedures for the registration of a bettor and establishment of a sports wagering account, including a procedure for:
Authenticating the age, identity and physical address of an applicant for a sports wagering account; and
Determining whether the applicant is a person prohibited from establishing or maintaining an account under applicable laws or regulations;
Procedures for terminating a registered bettor’s sports wagering account and the return of any funds remaining in the sports wagering account to the registered bettor;
Procedures for suspending or terminating a dormant account and the return of any funds remaining in the dormant account to the registered bettor;
Procedures for:
The logging in and authentication of a registered bettor to enable the bettor to commence sports wagering; and
The logging off of the registered bettor when the registered bettor has completed play;
Procedures to automatically log a registered bettor out of the registered bettor’s sports wagering account after a specified period of inactivity;
Procedures for the crediting and debiting of a registered bettor’s sports wagering account;
Procedures for cashing checks, receiving electronic negotiable instruments and for redeeming cash equivalents;
Procedures for withdrawing funds from a sports wagering account by the registered bettor;
Procedures for the protection of a registered bettor’s funds, including the segregation of a registered bettor’s funds from operating funds of the sports wagering licensee;
Procedures to account for and safeguard money generated from the conduct of sports wagering;

Procedures for the security and sharing of personally identifiable information of a registered bettor, value of funds in a sports wagering account, and other information as required by the Commission;
Procedures by which a sports wagering licensee will provide notice to a registered bettor related to the sharing of personally identifiable information;
Procedures and security for the calculation and recordation of revenue;
Procedures for the security of sports wagering equipment;
Procedures and security standards as to receipt, handling and storage of sports wagering equipment;
Procedures and appropriate measures implemented to deter, detect and prevent cheating;
Procedures for identifying and reporting fraudulent, suspicious, or unusual wagering activity;

Procedures to govern emergencies, including suspected or actual cyber-attacks, hacking or tampering with the sports wagering licensee’s sports wagering platform, sports wagering website and sports wagering equipment;
Procedures for the reconciliation or repayment of a registered bettor’s sports wagering account;
Procedures for automated and manual risk management;
Procedures for compliance with AML standards;
Description of all integrated third-party hardware, software, or systems;
Procedures to identify a wager or attempts to wager above any maximum wager threshold set by the sports wagering licensee;
Procedures to be utilized by an employee of a sports wagering licensee in the event of a malfunction of sports wagering licensee’s:
Sports wagering website;
Sports wagering platform; or
Sports wagering equipment; and
Any other items the Commission may request in writing to be included in the internal controls.

Prior to authorizing a sports wagering licensee to commence the conduct of sports wagering, the Commission shall review and approve the system of internal controls, security protocols, and audit protocols submitted under this chapter to determine whether these controls and protocols conform to the requirements of this chapter and whether they provide adequate and effective controls for the conduct of sports wagering.
A sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission a catalog of the type of events that it intends to accept wagers on as well as the type of wagers it intends to accept.
A sports wagering licensee shall notify the Commission of any changes to the catalogue at least 72 hours in advance of implementation of these changes.
A sports wagering licensee shall continually maintain a catalog of all prior and current events and the types of wagers it offered on the events.

At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence or another timeframe as approved by the Commission, a sports wagering licensee shall submit its internal controls to the Commission for review and written approval.
The internal controls shall be accompanied by:

A certification by the sports wagering licensee’s chief executive officer or chief legal officer that the submitted internal controls conform to the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1E, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter;
A certification by the sports wagering licensee’s director of finance that the submitted internal controls:
Establish a consistent overall system of internal controls;
Provide reasonable assurance that financial reporting conforms to generally accepted accounting principles in the United States; and
Conform to the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1E, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter; and
An opinion letter by an independent certified public accountant expressing an opinion as to:
The effectiveness of the design of the submitted system of internal controls over financial reporting;
Whether the submitted system of internal controls conforms to the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1E, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter; and

If applicable, whether a deviation from the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1E, Annotated Code of Maryland, or this chapter identified by the independent certified public accountant in the course of its review of the submitted system of internal controls is material.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its internal controls are approved in writing by the Commission.
If the Commission determines that a submitted internal control is deficient, the Commission shall:
Provide the sports wagering licensee with written notice of the deficiency;
Require the sports wagering licensee to revise the internal control as appropriate; and
Request the sports wagering licensee to resubmit the internal controls to the Commission for review and approval.
A sports wagering licensee may not implement a change or amendment in its approved internal controls without the prior written approval of the Commission.

A sports wagering licensee’s initial internal controls submission and a change or amendment to its approved internal controls shall be reviewed and approved in accordance with a process and time frame developed and implemented by the Commission.
The process developed by the Commission under §F of this regulation shall, at a minimum, require the sports wagering licensee to:
Submit a redlined copy of any section of the approved internal controls to be changed or amended with added text underlined and deleted text lined out;
Document on the redlined copy the date the Commission approved the section to be changed or amended and the date the revision was submitted to the Commission for review;
Submit a narrative explaining the reason for the change or amendment which includes the sports wagering licensee’s target date for implementation;
Submit the written representations required in §B(1) and (2) of this regulation with regard to the proposed change or amendment; and
Mark each page of approved internal controls with the date on which it was approved by the Commission.
The Commission may require a sports wagering licensee to submit daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annual reports of financial and statistical data.
Reports required under this regulation shall be in a form and submitted in accordance with a time frame specified by the Commission.
Unless otherwise specified by the Commission, reports to the Commission shall be signed by the:
Chief executive officer if the sports wagering licensee is a corporation;
General partner if the sports wagering licensee is a partnership;
Manager if the sports wagering licensee is a limited liability company;
Chief executive officer or functional equivalent if the sports wagering licensee is any other form of business association; or
Owner if the sports wagering licensee is a sole proprietorship.
A sports wagering licensee shall submit a report to the Commission on the due date specified by the Commission unless an extension has been approved in writing by the Commission.
The Commission may, on written notice to a sports wagering licensee, require an interim report to be submitted in a form and in accordance with a time frame specified by the Commission.

section.heading: Annual Audit and Other Regulatory Reports.

para.text: A sports wagering licensee shall cause its annual financial statements to be audited in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards by an independent certified public accountant.

The annual financial statements shall be prepared on a comparative basis for the current and prior fiscal year and present financial position and results of operations in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.

The audited financial statements shall include a footnote reconciling and explaining any difference between the financial statements included in any report submitted to the Commission under Regulation .06 of this chapter and the audited financial statements.
A sports wagering licensee shall with regard to adjustments resulting from the annual audit:
Disclose to the Commission all adjustments whether or not recorded in the accounting records; and
Record the adjustment in the accounting records of the year to which the adjustment relates.
No later than 90 days after the end of its fiscal year, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission:
A copy of its audited financial statements; and
Any management letter or report prepared with regard to the financial statements by its independent certified public accountant.

A sports wagering licensee shall require the independent certified public accountant auditing its financial statements or other qualified entity approved by the Commission to render the following additional reports:
A report identifying:
Material weaknesses or significant deficiencies in the sports wagering licensee’s Commission-approved internal controls noted in the course of the examination of the financial statements; and
Recommendations as to how to eliminate each material weakness or significant deficiency identified; and

A report assessing the adequacy and effectiveness of the sports wagering licensee’s information technology security controls and system configurations with recommendations as to how to eliminate each material weakness or significant deficiency identified.
A sports wagering licensee shall prepare a written response to the reports required by §F of this regulation which includes details as to any corrective action taken.
No later than 120 days after the end of its fiscal year, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission a copy of:
The reports required under §F of this regulation;
The response required under §G of this regulation; and
Any other report on internal controls or other matters relative to its accounting or operating procedures rendered by its independent certified public accountant.
If a sports wagering licensee or any of its affiliates are publicly held, the sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission a copy of:
Any report required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission including:
Form S-1;
Form 8-K;
Form 10-Q;
Form 10-K;
Proxy statement;
Information statement; and
Registration statement; and
Any other report required to be filed with a domestic or foreign securities regulatory agency.
A report required to be filed under §I of this regulation shall be submitted to the Commission no later than 10 days after the date of filing with the applicable agency.
A sports wagering licensee shall submit a written report to the Commission if an independent certified public accountant who is engaged as the principal accountant to audit its financial statements:
Resigns;
Is dismissed as the sports wagering licensee’s principal accountant; or
Is replaced by another independent certified public accountant as principal accountant.
A report required to be filed under §K of this regulation shall include:
The date of the resignation, dismissal, or new engagement;

Whether in connection with the audits of the two most recent years preceding a resignation, dismissal, or new engagement there were any disagreements, resolved or unresolved, with the former accountant on:
Accounting principles or practices;
Financial statement disclosure; or
Auditing scope or procedure;
The nature of any disagreement disclosed in §L(2) of this regulation;
Whether the principal accountant’s report on the financial statements for either of the past 2 years contained an adverse opinion or disclaimer of opinion or was qualified;
The nature of any adverse opinion, disclaimer of opinion, or qualification; and

A letter from the former principal accountant addressed to the Commission stating whether the principal accountant concurs with the statements made by the sports wagering licensee in the report to the Commission submitted under this section.

A report required to be filed under §K of this regulation shall be submitted to the Commission no later than 10 days after the end of the month in which the resignation, dismissal, or new engagement occurred.

No later than 7 days after the date of filing with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, a sports wagering licensee shall provide the Commission with access to each Suspicious Activity Report filed under 31 CFR §103.21.

A sports wagering licensee or a director, officer, employee, or agent of a sports wagering licensee who reports suspicious activity under 31 CFR §103.21 may not notify an individual involved in the suspicious activity that the suspicious activity has been reported.

No later than 7 days after the date of filing with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, a sports wagering licensee provide with the Commission with access to each Currency Transaction Report filed under 31 CFR §103.22.
At least 30 days before sports wagering operations are to commence, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission a copy of its compliance program required under 31 CFR §103.64.
On or before the effective date, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission any change or amendment to its compliance program required under 31 CFR §103.64.
All original books and records shall be:
Prepared and maintained in a complete, accurate, and legible form;
Stored in a format that ensures readability, regardless of whether the technology or software that created or maintains it has become obsolete;
Retained in a secure location equipped with a fire notification system:
At the sports wagering licensee’s facility; or
An off-site location approved by the Commission under §F of this regulation for the express purpose of document storage;
Kept immediately available for inspection by the Commission during all hours of operation;
Organized and indexed in a manner designed to provide immediate accessibility to the Commission; and
Destroyed only after expiration of the minimum retention period required under this regulation.

The Commission may, on submission of a written request or alternate record retention schedule by a sports wagering licensee, authorize destruction prior to the expiration of the minimum retention period required under this regulation.

Unless a request for destruction or alternate record retention schedule is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission, a sports wagering licensee shall retain indefinitely original books and records documenting:
Ownership of the sports wagering licensee’s facility if applicable;
Internally initiated investigations and due diligence;
Personnel matters;
Signature cards of current employees; and
Destruction of documents, including:
The identity of the document;
Period of retention; and
Date of destruction.

Unless a request for destruction or alternate record retention schedule is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission, a sports wagering licensee shall retain for a minimum of 5 years all original books and records not:
Identified for indefinite retention under §C of this regulation; or
Subject to an exception under §E of this regulation.
Exceptions. The following exceptions apply to the retention period in §D of this regulation:
A minimum retention period of 5 years shall apply to documentation pertaining to cashiers’ cage transactions;
A minimum retention period of 5 years shall apply to:
Signature cards of terminated employees;
Insurance records relating to claims by bettors;
Surveillance and security department:
Employee duty logs;
Visitor logs;
Incident logs;
Recording logs; and
Equipment malfunction reports; and
Documentation pertaining to sports wagering tickets or promotional play instruments reported to the Commission as possibly counterfeit, altered, or tampered with;
A minimum retention period of 30 days shall apply to:
Cancelled promotional play instruments for which all reconciliations required by the sports wagering licensee’s approved internal controls have been conducted and resolved;
Voided sports wagering tickets; and
Sports wagering tickets and vouchers redeemed at a facility other than through a ticket redemption unit or kiosk.
On submission of a written request by the sports wagering licensee, the Commission may approve a location outside the facility to store original books and records.
A sports wagering licensee requesting to store original books and records outside the facility shall submit to the Commission:
A description of the proposed location, including details with regard to security and fire notification systems;
Details with regard to the ownership of the proposed location; and
Procedures for Commission access to original books and records retained at the proposed location.
A sports wagering licensee may not store books and records outside the facility without the prior written approval of the Commission.
On submission of a written request by a sports wagering licensee, the Commission may approve a suitable media system for the copying and storage of original books and records.
A sports wagering licensee submitting a system for the copying and storage of original books and records shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Commission that the:
Processing, preservation, and maintenance methods to be utilized will make books and records readily available for review and reproduction;
Inspection and quality control methods to be utilized will ensure that when books and records are viewed or reproduced they will exhibit a high degree of legibility and readability;
Equipment necessary to readily locate, read, and reproduce books and records is available to the Commission at the location or approved off-site location; and

Detailed index of all stored data maintained and arranged to facilitate the immediate location of particular books and records is available to the Commission at the location or approved off-site location.
A sports wagering licensee may not utilize a media system for the copying and storage of original books and records without the prior written approval of the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee may utilize the services of a contractor for the destruction of books and records permitted to be destroyed under this regulation.

Nothing in this regulation shall be construed as relieving a sports wagering licensee of any obligation to prepare or maintain books and records required by any other federal, State, or local governmental entity.
Requirements.

A sports wagering licensee shall be under the authority of the County Alcoholic Beverages Licensing Authority for the county in which the facility is located with regard to the sale to individuals of food and alcoholic beverages.
Except as provided in this section, a sports wagering licensee may not provide food or alcoholic beverages to individuals at no cost.

Food or alcoholic beverages offered by a sports wagering licensee for sale to individuals may be offered only at prices that are determined by the County Alcoholic Beverages Licensing Authority to be commensurate with the price of similar types of food and alcoholic beverages at restaurants in the county in which the facility is located.

A sports wagering licensee may provide food at no cost to individuals to the same extent allowed under Alcoholic Beverages Article §5-303, Annotated Code of Maryland, for a person engaged in the sale or barter of spirituous, malt, or intoxicating liquors and licensed in Maryland.
A sports wagering licensee shall develop, maintain, and implement adequate written internal controls over the authorization and provision of complimentary services.

A sports wagering licensee shall at all times make available to the Commission the internal controls required under §B of this regulation but is not required to include them in the system of internal controls submitted to the Commission for approval under Regulation .05 of this chapter.
A sports wagering licensee shall collect and retain data pertaining to the cost of, and number of individuals provided with, each category of complimentary services.
Report.
A sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission a quarterly report summarizing complimentary services provided during the reporting period.
The report shall include calendar year-to-date totals of complimentary services provided.
The report shall be submitted:
On or before the 15th day of the month following the end of each quarter; or
At the request of the Commission.
The report required under §E of this regulation shall:
Separate complimentary services into the following categories:
Rooms;
Food and Beverage;
Travel;
Gifts:
Cash; and
Noncash; and
Other; and
Determine the cost of complimentary services provided to a bettor as follows:

Complimentary services offered by a sports wagering licensee in the normal course of business shall be reported at an amount based upon the full retail price normally charged for the service by the sports wagering licensee;

Complimentary services not offered for sale by the sports wagering licensee in the normal course of business but provided directly by the sports wagering licensee to the bettor shall be reported at an amount based upon the actual cost to the sports wagering licensee of providing the service;

Complimentary services provided directly or indirectly on behalf of a sports wagering licensee by a third party not related to the sports wagering licensee shall be reported at an amount based upon the actual cost to the sports wagering licensee of having the third party provide the service; and

Complimentary services provided directly or indirectly on behalf of a sports wagering licensee by a third party related to the sports wagering licensee shall be reported at an amount based upon the actual cost to the third party of providing the service.

A sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission a report identifying a bettor who, together with guests, received $5,000 or more in complimentary services within a period of 5 consecutive days.
The report required by §G of this regulation shall:
State the reason complimentary services were provided;
Include the bettor’s rating in the sports wagering licensee’s bettor rating system at the time the complimentary services were provided;
Disclose the total amount, including year-to-date totals, provided in complimentary services separated into the following categories:
Rooms;
Food and beverage;
Travel;
Gifts:
Cash; and
Noncash; and
Other; and
Be submitted:
At least quarterly, by the 15th day of the month following the end of each quarter; or
At the request of the Commission.

For the purposes of this regulation, the title used to describe a department head is intended to indicate responsibility for the functions of the enumerated department and does not obligate the sports wagering licensee to the use of that particular title.
Subject to the requirements of this regulation, a sports wagering licensee shall tailor its table of organization to meet its needs and policies.

At least 30 days before sports wagering operations are to commence, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval a table of organization depicting all direct and indirect reporting lines for:
The chief executive officer required under §E(5) of this regulation;
Mandatory departments required under §E(6) of this regulation; and
If applicable, the cashiers’ cage manager required under §M of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until the table of organization submitted under §C of this regulation is approved in writing by the Commission.
The holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license’s table of organization shall include:
A system of personnel and chain of command which permits management and supervisory personnel to be held accountable for actions or omissions within their areas of responsibility;
The segregation of incompatible functions, duties, and responsibilities so that no individual is in a position to both:
Commit an error or to perpetrate a fraud; and
Conceal the error or fraud in the normal course of the individual’s duties;
All functions, duties, and responsibilities of qualified personnel;
Areas of responsibility which are not so extensive as to be impractical for one individual to monitor;
A chief executive officer:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Ultimately responsible for the daily conduct of all sports wagering business; and
The following mandatory departments and supervisors:
A surveillance department supervised by a director of surveillance:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Subject to the reporting requirements of §I of this regulation;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the surveillance of all aspects of sports wagering operations;
An internal audit department supervised by a director of internal audit:
Based for employment purposes at the facility if applicable;
Subject to the reporting requirements of §G of this regulation;
Licensed as a principal employee; and

Responsible for assessing compliance with approved internal controls, applicable laws and regulations, the reliability of financial reporting, deterring and investigating fraud, and the safeguarding of assets;
An information technology department supervised by a director of information technology:
Based for employment purposes at the facility if applicable;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the quality, reliability, accuracy, and security of all sports wagering platforms and associated equipment and software utilized by the sports wagering licensee;
A security department supervised by a director of security:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the overall security of the facility;
An accounting department supervised by a director of finance:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for all accounting and finance functions including the control and supervision of the cashiers’ cage, satellite cages, and count room; and
A sports wagering department supervised by a director of sports wagering operations:
Based for employment purposes at the facility if applicable;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the operation and conduct of sports wagering.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements set forth in §E of this regulation.

The director of surveillance and the director of internal audit required under §E(6) of this regulation shall be independent of the chief executive officer regarding matters of policy, purpose, responsibility, and authority and shall report directly to:
An individual based for employment purposes at the facility, if applicable, with no incompatible functions; or
An audit committee of:
The sports wagering licensee; or
A Commission-authorized licensed affiliate of the sports wagering licensee.

The individual or audit committee to whom the director of surveillance and the director of internal audit report under §G of this regulation shall also control the hiring, termination, and salary of the director.
The director of surveillance and the director of internal audit may report to the chief executive officer with regard to daily operations.
Mandatory departments and the supervisors over them shall cooperate with, yet perform independently of, all other mandatory departments and supervisory positions.
A sports wagering licensee may designate more than one individual to serve jointly as the director of a mandatory department required by §E of this regulation.
A joint director of a mandatory department under §K of this regulation shall be:
Based for employment purposes at the facility if applicable; and
Individually and jointly accountable and responsible for the operation of the department.
A department that is not mandatory may operate under, or in conjunction with, a mandatory department where the table of organization is consistent with the requirements of §E of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee’s cashiers’ cage manager shall be licensed as a principal employee for:
The holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license; and
The holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license if required by the Commission.

On any shift for which the cashiers’ cage manager is not present in the facility, the cashiers’ cage shift manager responsible for the cashiers’ cage shall be licensed as a principal employee unless another principal employee required by this regulation is present at the facility for:
The holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license; and
The holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license if required by the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee may not implement a change in the table of organization approved by the Commission under §E or F of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee shall ensure that an employee is trained in the policies, procedures, and internal controls relevant to the individual’s function.
Vacancy. If there is a vacancy in the chief executive officer position or any mandatory department director position required by §E or F of this regulation, the following shall apply:
No later than 5 days after the date of a vacancy, a sports wagering licensee shall notify the Commission in writing of:
The vacant position;
The date on which the position will become or became vacant; and
The date on which the sports wagering licensee anticipates that the vacancy will be filled on a permanent basis;
No later than 30 days after the date of a vacancy, a sports wagering licensee shall fill the vacant position on a temporary basis;
No later than 120 days after the original date of the vacancy, a sports wagering licensee shall fill the vacant position on a permanent basis; and
No later than 5 days after filling a vacancy, a sports wagering licensee shall notify the Commission in writing of:
The vacant position filled;
The name of the individual designated to fill the position;
The date that the vacancy was filled; and
Whether the vacancy has been filled on a temporary or permanent basis.

section.heading: Surveillance System Design Standards for Class A and Class B-1 Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee shall install in its facility a surveillance system that complies with the requirements of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance system shall be reviewed and approved by the Commission under Regulation .11 of this chapter.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance system shall include:
Light sensitive cameras enabled by:
Lenses of sufficient magnification to monitor activity at each betting window, kiosk and other sports wagering related areas and activities in a facility;
Lighting which is continuous and of sufficient quality to produce clear video recordings and still pictures; and
360-degree pan, tilt, and zoom capability, without camera stops, configured to clandestinely monitor and record:
Transactions conducted at each betting window, kiosk and other sports wagering related areas and activities in a facility;
Transactions conducted in the cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage including the face of each individual transacting business with a cashier;
Transactions conducted at ticket redemption units and automated teller machines;
Activity in the count room;
Movement of cash and cash storage boxes within the facility;
Entrances and exits to the facility;
Activities in all other restricted areas; and
Other areas and events designated by the Commission;
A monitor room located in the facility:
Staffed by employees of the sports wagering licensee’s surveillance department 24 hours per day; and
Equipped with:
A communication system capable of monitoring all security department communications;
Connections, direct or through a documented communication protocol with the security department, to all facility alarm systems;
A surveillance failure notification system that provides an audible, as well as a visual notification, of any failure in the surveillance system or the digital video recording media storage system;

An emergency power system, tested by the sports wagering licensee in the presence of the Commission at least once a year, which can be used to operate the surveillance system in the event of a power failure;
Computer terminals permitting event notification to, and read only access by authorized surveillance department employees to, the Class A licensee’s sports wagering platform;
An updated photo library, consisting of photographs that are no more than 5 years old, of all current employees of the facility;
A copy of the Class A sport wagering facility licensee’s floor plan required under COMAR 36.03.10.17.04B;
A copy of the procedures addressing the evacuation of the facility in the event of fire or other emergency required under Regulation .13 of this chapter; and
Copies of the surveillance system contingency plans required under Regulation .11 of this chapter;
Digital video recording capability equipped to:
Superimpose the date and time on all monitoring and recording;
Identify and locate, through the use of a meter, counter, or other device or method, a particular event which was recorded;
Identify on video recording disks or other storage media the type of media player and software prerequisite to viewing the digital images; and
Be authenticated through use of an embedded video verification encryption code or watermark;
Audio recording capability in the count room that is:
Installed and disclosed to employees of the facility; and
Consistent with the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article, §§10-401—10-414, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
An access system which:
Controls:
Physical and logical access to the surveillance system; and
Physical access to the surveillance monitor room; and
Restricts access to the security administration capabilities of the system.

A sports wagering licensee shall configure its surveillance system to record all areas and transactions enumerated in §E(1) of this regulation with a resolution of 4 common image format at a minimum of:
For a standard definition camera, 30 frames per second; or
For a high-definition camera, 15 frames per second.

A sports wagering licensee may configure its surveillance system to record activity in areas of the facility not covered by §E of this regulation at a reduced frame rate with a resolution of 4 common image format, as follows:
Public areas shall be recorded at a minimum frame rate of 15 frames per second; and
Areas not accessible to the public shall be recorded at a minimum frame rate of 7.5 frames per second.
Except as provided in §I of this regulation, a sports wagering licensee shall retain surveillance recordings:
For a minimum of 7 days for transactions or events in the areas covered under §E of this regulation; and
For a minimum of 14 days for transactions or events in the areas covered under §F of this regulation.

Upon the request of the Commission or a law enforcement agency that has proper jurisdiction over the facility, a recording shall be retained and stored in accordance with the directives of the Commission or law enforcement agency pertaining to that recording.
Except as provided in this regulation, a surveillance system shall be under the exclusive control of a sports wagering licensee’s surveillance department.
A sports wagering licensee shall provide the Commission with timely and unfettered access to its surveillance monitor room, surveillance system, and all transmissions.
A sports wagering licensee shall timely comply with a request from the Commission to:
Use, as necessary, any monitor room in the facility;
Display on the monitors in its monitor room or in the Commission’s on-site monitor room any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system;
Relinquish control of a camera or monitor;
Discontinue monitoring a particular camera or recording activity captured by it;
Make a video recording or photograph of any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system; and
Restrict or deny access to a recording or photograph.
A surveillance system may not be remotely accessed from a facility outside the surveillance monitor room without the prior written approval of the Commission.
An entrance to a surveillance monitor room may not be visible from the facility floor.

section.heading: Surveillance Department Operating Procedures for Class A and Class B-1 Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.
At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval:
A surveillance system meeting the requirements of Regulation .10 of this chapter including, at a minimum, details pertaining to:
Camera configuration inside and outside the facility;
Monitor room configuration;
Video recording format and configuration specifications;
Authentication of digital recordings, including Commission access to the system’s video verification encryption code or watermark;
Audio recording format; and
System access controls; and
Surveillance department operating procedures conforming to this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its surveillance system and surveillance department operating procedures are approved in writing by the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance department operating procedures shall, at a minimum, require:
Coverage of all areas and transactions enumerated in Regulation .10 of this chapter;
Contingency plans addressing:
Full and partial failure of the surveillance system including:
A contact list with telephone numbers for individuals required to be notified in the event of a failure; and
Facility closure protocols; and
Planned shutdown of the surveillance system;
A surveillance incident log to:
Be maintained by monitor room employees in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Document the scheduled coverage in §D(1) of this regulation and all other non-routine surveillance activity as follows:
Date and time surveillance is commenced;
Name and Commission license number of the individual initiating, performing, or supervising the surveillance;
Reason for the surveillance;
Whether the suspicious activity involves an alleged regulatory violation or criminal activity;
Name, if known, alias, or description of an individual being monitored;
Description of the activity in which the individual being monitored is engaged;
Reading on a meter, counter, or device that identifies the point on the video recording at which the event occurred;
Time at which a video recording is commenced and terminated, if different than when surveillance is commenced or terminated;
Date and time surveillance is terminated;
Summary of the results of the surveillance; and
Description of the time, date, and cause of any equipment or camera malfunction which occurred during the conduct of surveillance;
A surveillance room entry log to:
Be Signed by an individual entering the surveillance monitor room who is not a surveillance department employee assigned to the monitor room’s work shift at the time of entry;
Be maintained by monitor room employees in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Document the following:
Date and time of entering the monitor room;
The entering individual’s name and department or affiliation;
The reason for entering the monitor room;
The name of the individual authorizing the individual’s entry into the monitor room; and
The date and time of exiting the monitor room;
That surveillance monitor room employees notify:
Security department supervisory personnel within 5 minutes of an incident of equipment failure affecting coverage of the facility; and
The Commission within 30 minutes of an incident of equipment failure affecting coverage of the facility citing:
Date and time;
Cause of the malfunction; and
Time a sports wagering licensee’s security department was notified of the malfunction;
That a sports wagering licensee confirm in writing a notice given verbally to the Commission under §D(5) of this regulation; and
That, on a daily basis, a sports wagering licensee synchronize the date and time on the surveillance system to the date and time on a public time server.

A sports wagering licensee may not implement a change or amendment in its surveillance system or surveillance department operating procedures approved by the Commission under §C of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.
Surveillance department employees shall be reasonably segregated and independent of all other departments at the facility.
A surveillance department employee may not transfer to any other department in the facility without the prior written approval of the Commission.

section.heading: Surveillance Department Minimum Staffing for Class A and Class B-1 Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.

At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence, a sports wagering licensee shall submit its surveillance department minimum staffing plan to the Commission for review and written approval.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its surveillance department minimum staffing plan is approved in writing by the Commission.
A surveillance department minimum staffing plan shall assess, on a per-shift basis, the minimum number of on duty surveillance department employees necessary to:
Provide adequate and effective surveillance of all activities in and outside the facility;
Ensure the physical safety of employees of and invitees to the facility;
Comply with all applicable laws and regulations including Commission-approved internal controls and operating procedures;
Monitor the facility to ensure that the following individuals are identified, prohibited from entering the facility, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility:
An intoxicated individual; or
An excluded individual; and

Monitor the facility floor to ensure that an individual younger than 21 years old is identified, prohibited from accessing the facility floor in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1E-11(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility floor.
A sports wagering licensee’s proposed surveillance department minimum staffing plan shall consider:
Square footage and layout of the facility;
Use of fixed and roving security posts;
Activity level on a per-shift basis and identify it as slow, normal, or peak;
Department supervisory needs; and
A limit of one employee per monitor station.

A sports wagering licensee may not implement a change or amendment in the surveillance department minimum staffing plan approved by the Commission under §C of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.

section.heading: Surveillance System Design Standards for Class B Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: This regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class B sports wagering facility license.
A sports wagering licensee shall install in its facility a surveillance system that complies with the requirements of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance system shall be reviewed and approved by the Commission under Regulation .14 of this chapter.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance system shall include:
Light sensitive cameras that are:
Enabled by lenses of sufficient magnification to monitor activity at each betting window, kiosk and other sports wagering related areas and activities in the facility;
Enabled by lighting which is continuous and of sufficient quality to produce clear video recordings and still pictures; and
Configured to clandestinely monitor and record:
Transactions conducted at each betting window, kiosk and other sports wagering related areas and activities in the facility;
Transactions conducted at cashier locations including the face of each individual transacting business with a cashier;
Transactions conducted at automated teller machines;
Activity in the count room;
Movement of cash and cash storage boxes within the facility;
Entrances and exits to the facility;
Activities in all other restricted areas; and
Other areas and events designated by the Commission; and
Digital video recording capability equipped to:
Superimpose the date and time on all monitoring and recording;
Identify and locate, through the use of a meter, counter or other device or method, a particular event which was recorded; and
Identify on video recording disks or other storage media the type of media player and software prerequisite to viewing the digital images.
Except as provided in §F of this regulation, a sports wagering licensee shall retain surveillance recordings for a minimum of 7 days.

Upon the request of the Commission or a law enforcement agency that has proper jurisdiction over the facility, a recording shall be retained and stored in accordance with the directives of the Commission or law enforcement agency pertaining to that recording.
A sports wagering licensee shall provide the Commission with timely and unfettered access to its surveillance monitor room, surveillance system and all transmissions.
A sports wagering licensee shall comply in a timely fashion with a request from the Commission to:
Use, as necessary, any monitor room in the facility;
Display on the monitors in its monitor room any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system;
Relinquish control of a camera or monitor;
Discontinue monitoring a particular camera or recording activity captured by it;
Make a video recording or photograph of any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system; and
Restrict or deny access to a recording or photograph.
A surveillance system may not be remotely accessed from a location outside the surveillance monitor room without the prior written approval of the Commission.

section.heading: Surveillance Department Operating Procedures for Class B Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: This regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class B sports wagering facility license.
At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval:
A surveillance system meeting the requirements of Regulation .13 of this chapter including, at a minimum, details pertaining to:
Camera configuration inside and outside the facility;
Monitor room configuration;
Video recording format and configuration specifications;
Authentication of digital recordings, including Commission access to the system’s video verification encryption code or watermark;
Audio recording format; and
System access controls; and
Surveillance department operating procedures conforming to this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its surveillance system and surveillance department operating procedures are approved in writing by the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance department operating procedures shall, at a minimum, require:
Coverage of all areas and transactions as enumerated in Regulation .13 of this chapter;
Contingency plans addressing a full or partial failure of the surveillance system;
A surveillance system access log that documents:
The date and time the surveillance system is accessed by an individual;
The accessing individual’s name and department or affiliation;
The reason for accessing the surveillance system; and
The date and time the individual ended their access of the surveillance system;
The sports wagering licensee to notify the Commission within 12 hours of an equipment failure affecting coverage of the facility citing:
The date and time of the failure;
The cause of the failure;
The length of time the surveillance system was inoperable or malfunctioning; and
The length of time the before the surveillance system is expected to be operable or have the malfunction to be corrected;
The sports wagering licensee to confirm in writing a notice given verbally to the Commission under §D(4) of this regulation; and
On a daily basis, the sports wagering licensee to synchronize the date and time on the surveillance system to a public time server.

A sports wagering licensee may not implement a change or amendment in its surveillance system or surveillance department operating procedures approved by the Commission under §B of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.

section.heading: Surveillance System Design Standards for Mobile Sports Wagering Licensees.

para.text: This regulation is only applicable to the holder of a mobile sports wagering license.
A sports wagering licensee shall install in each of the licensee’s data information centers and operations centers a surveillance system that complies with the requirements of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance system shall be reviewed and approved by the Commission under Regulation .16 of this chapter.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance system shall include:
Light sensitive cameras that are:
Enabled by lenses of sufficient magnification to observe front and back of each server cabinet that house all servers that collectively are the online wagering and associated systems;
Enabled by lighting which is continuous and of sufficient quality to produce clear video recordings and still pictures; and
Configured to monitor and record physical access to the online wagering and associated systems; and
Digital video recording capability equipped to:
Superimpose the date and time on all monitoring and recording;
Through the use of a meter, counter or other device or method, identify and locate a particular event which was recorded; and
Identify on video recording disks or other storage media the type of media player and software prerequisite to viewing the digital images.
Except as provided in §F of this regulation, a sports wagering licensee shall retain surveillance recordings for a minimum of 90 days.

Upon the request of the Commission or a law enforcement agency that has proper jurisdiction over the sports wagering licensee, a recording shall be retained and stored in accordance with the directives of the Commission or law enforcement agency pertaining to that recording.
A sports wagering licensee shall provide the Commission with timely and unfettered remote access to its surveillance system and all transmissions.
A sports wagering licensee shall comply in a timely fashion with a request from the Commission to:
Display on monitors any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system;
Make a video recording or photograph of any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system; and
Restrict or deny access to a recording or photograph.
A surveillance system may not be directly accessible from a location outside a mobile sports wagering licensee’s local network.

section.heading: Surveillance Department Operating Procedures for Mobile Sports Wagering Licensees.

para.text: This regulation is only applicable to the holder of a mobile sports wagering license.
At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval:
A surveillance system meeting the requirements of Regulation .15 of this chapter including, at a minimum, details pertaining to:
Camera configuration inside and outside the data information centers and operations centers;
Monitor room configuration;
Video recording format and configuration specifications;
Authentication of digital recordings, including Commission access to the system’s video verification encryption code or watermark;
Audio recording format; and
System access controls; and
Surveillance department operating procedures conforming to this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its surveillance system and surveillance department operating procedures are approved in writing by the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee’s surveillance department operating procedures shall, at a minimum, require:
Coverage of all areas and transactions as enumerated in Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Contingency plans addressing a full or partial failure of the surveillance system;
A surveillance system access log that documents:
The date and time the surveillance system is accessed by an individual;
The accessing individual’s name and department or affiliation;
The reason for accessing the surveillance system; and
The date and time the individual ended their access of the surveillance system;
The sports wagering licensee to notify the Commission within 12 hours of an equipment failure affecting coverage of the facility citing:
The date and time of the failure;
The cause of the failure;
The length of time the surveillance system was inoperable or malfunctioning; and
The length of time the before the surveillance system is expected to be or operable or the malfunction to be corrected;
The sports wagering licensee to confirm in writing a notice given verbally to the Commission under §D(4) of this regulation; and
On a daily basis, the sports wagering licensee to synchronize the date and time on the surveillance system to Eastern Standard Time.

A sports wagering licensee may not implement a change or amendment in its surveillance system or surveillance department operating procedures approved by the Commission under §B of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.

section.heading: Security Department Operating Procedures for Class A and Class B-1 Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.

At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence or another time approved by the Commission, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval its security department operating procedures.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its security department operating procedures are approved in writing by the Commission.
A sports wagering licensee’s security department operating procedures shall, at a minimum, include:
A security zone plan for the facility, employing fixed security posts and roving security officers designed to ensure:
The physical safety of employees of and invitees to the facility;
The safeguarding of assets;
Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations including Commission approved internal controls and operating procedures;
That the following individuals are identified, prohibited from entering the facility, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility:
An intoxicated individual; or
An excluded individual; and

That an individual younger than 21 years old is identified, prohibited from accessing the facility floor in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1E-11(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility floor;
Procedures and controls addressing:
Facility access controls including:
An access badge system;
If utilized, specifications pertaining to a computerized access control system; and
Administrative responsibility over a manual or computerized access control system;
A temporary access credential;
Key controls;
Emergency alarm and fire command responsibilities including communication protocols with the surveillance department;
Evacuation of the facility in the event of fire or other emergency;
The identification and immediate removal of an intoxicated individual, an individual younger than 21 years old, an excluded individual;
Bettor disputes under Regulation .37 of this chapter; and
The notice requirements of §E(4) of this regulation;
A security department incident log:
Maintained by security department employees in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Documenting the following:
Assignment number of the incident;
Date and time;
Name and Commission license of the department member covering the incident;
Nature of the incident; and
Resolution of the incident; and
A requirement that a sports wagering licensee notice the Commission on detection of:
An individual engaged in, attempting to engage in, or suspected of cheating, theft, embezzlement, or other illegal activities; or
An individual who is:
Younger than 21 years old;
Intoxicated; or
An excluded individual.

section.heading: Security Department Minimum Staffing for Class A and Class B-1 Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is applicable only to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B-1 sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.

At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are to commence or another time approved Commission, a sports wagering licensee shall submit its security department minimum staffing plan to the Commission for review and written approval.
A sports wagering licensee may not commence operations until its security department minimum staffing plan is approved in writing by the Commission.

section.heading: Security Department Operating Procedures for Class B Sports Wagering Facility Licensees.

para.text: This regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class B sports wagering facility license.
A sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval its security operating procedures.
A sports wagering licensee’s security operating procedures shall, at a minimum, include:
A security zone plan for the facility designed to ensure:
The physical safety of employees and invitees to the facility;
The safeguarding of assets;
Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations including Commission approved internal controls and operating procedures;
That intoxicated individuals are identified, prohibited from entering the facility and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility; and
That an individual younger than 21 years old is identified, prohibited from sports wagering and, if necessary immediately removed from the facility;
Procedures and controls addressing:
Facility access controls including:
An access badge or key system;
If utilized, specifications pertaining to a computerized access control system; and
Administrative responsibility over a manual or computerized access control system;
A temporary access credential;
Key controls;
Emergency alarm and fire command responsibilities;
Evacuation of the facility in the event of fire or other emergency;
The identification and immediate removal of an intoxicated individual, and, if applicable, an individual younger than 21 years old; and
The notice requirements of §C(4) of this regulation;
A security incident log:
Maintained in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Documenting:
The assignment number of the incident;
The date and time of the incident;
The name of the person covering the incident;
The nature of the incident; and
The resolution of the incident; and
A requirement that a Class B licensee notify the Commission upon detection of:
An individual engaged in, attempting to engage in, or suspected of cheating, theft, embezzlement, or other illegal activities; and
An individual who is:
Younger than 21 years old and has engaged in sports wagering; or
Intoxicated.
Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.

At least 60 days before sports wagering operations are set to commence or another time approved Commission, a sports wagering licensee shall submit to the Commission for review and approval internal audit department operating standards and procedures that:
Meet the requirements of Regulation .09E(6)(b) of this chapter;
Conform to this regulation; and
Ensure that an internal audit is conducted in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in the United States.
A sports wagering licensees internal audit department operating procedures and standards shall, at a minimum, require the internal audit department to:
Work independently of the departments of the sports wagering licensee that are subject to audit;
Assess whether the sports wagering licensees internal controls comply with applicable law and Commission directives;
Test the sports wagering licensees compliance with its internal controls;
Immediately report a deficiency in, or noncompliance with, the sports wagering licensees internal controls to:
The audit committee;
The chief executive officer;
Management; and
The Commission;
Recommend resolution for eliminating a deficiency in, or noncompliance with, the sports wagering licensees internal control system;
Meet periodically with the audit committee or director of internal audit;
Perform audits of:

Unless an alternate risk assessment and audit plan is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission, all departments of the sports wagering licensee that are designated under §§C and D of this regulation; and
A department of the sports wagering licensee designated by the Commission;
Prepare an audit report for each audit conducted;
Accurately document the audit process and results in an audit report that, at a minimum, shall include:
Audit objectives;
Audit procedures and scope;
Findings and conclusions;
A recommendation for addressing a deficiency in, or noncompliance with, the sports wagering licensees internal controls;
Resolution of all exceptions; and
Managements response;
Submit audit reports to the Commission on a schedule specified by the Commission; and
Verify that:
A deficiency or noncompliance revealed during an audit has been corrected; and
An exception disclosed during an audit has been resolved.
If applicable, the audit department shall audit at least semiannually the functions and operations of the sports wagering licensees:
Cashiers cage;
Collection of cash storage boxes;
Cash count;
Revenue audit;
Sports wagering operations department; and
Key control;
If applicable, the audit department shall audit at least annually:
Responsible gaming program;
Security department;
Currency transaction reporting;
Suspicious activity reporting;
Information technology controls;
Surveillance department;
Bettor tracking system; and
Sports wagering platform.
The internal audit department shall conduct an audit on an unannounced basis when possible.
The sports wagering licensee shall limit and control administrative access to the sports wagering platform and associated equipment by ensuring the following:
Maintain access configurations and procedures that meet industry best practices and adhere to nationally recognized information technology compliance standards;
Maintain logs of user access and review the logs daily to identify security incidents and unusual transactions;
Coordinate and develop an education and training program on information security and privacy matters for employees and other authorized users;
Ensure compliance with all State and federal information security policies and rules;
Prepare and maintain security-related reports and data;
Develop and implement an incident response plan to address security breaches, policy violations and complaints from external parties;

Develop and implement an ongoing risk assessment program that targets information security and privacy matters by identifying methods for vulnerability detection and remediation and overseeing the testing of those methods; and

Ensure remote access to a sports wagering licensee’s sports wagering platform and associated equipment is only permitted from within the local network and not directly accessible from the internet unless secured and monitored and approved by the MLGCC on a case-by-case basis.
All sports wagering licensee’s sports wagering platforms and associated equipment shall be available for independent testing by the Commission or the Commission’s designee.
Except as set forth in §B, this regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A sports wagering facility license.
The Commission may require the holder of a Class B sports wagering facility license to comply with any or all of the requirements of this regulation.
A sports wagering licensee shall have on, adjacent, or proximate to the facility floor a physical structure known as a cashiers’ cage to house the cashiers in the facility for:
The custody of the cash, accounting records, and forms and documents required under this chapter to conduct sports wagering operations;
The initial financial consolidation of all transactions pertaining to sports wagering activity; and
Other functions normally associated with the operation of a cashiers’ cage.
A cashiers’ cage shall include a manually triggered silent alarm system connected:
Directly to the security department; or
Directly, or through a documented communication protocol, to the monitor room of the surveillance department.
A sports wagering licensee shall make readily available to the Commission:
An access control matrix indicating which employee job descriptions are authorized to have access to the cashiers’ cage; and
A list of employees, with license number, who are authorized to:
Have access to the Cashiers’ cage;
Activate or deactivate alarm systems for the cashiers’ cage; and
Grant access to the cashiers’ cage through the access control matrix or a computerized access control system.

section.heading: Accounting Controls for a Cashiers’ Cage.

para.text: This regulation is only applicable to the holder of a Class A or Class B sports wagering facility license.

A sports wagering licensee may only conduct transactions with individuals at its cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.10.17.02.

A sports wagering licensee shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .04 of this chapter procedures addressing the segregation of the cashiers’ cage and the general conduct of cashiers’ cage transactions.
A sports wagering licensee’s internal controls shall require:
The cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage to be physically segregated by personnel and function as follows:
General cashiers shall be responsible for:
An individual imprest inventory of cash;
Receipt and payout of cash, negotiable instruments, sports wagering tickets, and other documentation from and to bettors subject to the limitations imposed under this chapter; and
Other functions designated by the sports wagering licensee which are not incompatible with the functions of a general cashier; and
Main bank cashiers shall be responsible for:
Receipt of cash, negotiable instruments, sports wagering tickets, and other documentation from general cashiers in exchange for cash or documentation;
Replenishment of kiosks;
Receipt of unsecured cash and unsecured sports wagering tickets;
Receipt of cash and documentation from the count room;
Preparation of the overall cashiers’ cage reconciliation;
Preparation of bank deposits; and
Other functions designated by the sports wagering licensee which are not incompatible with the functions of a main bank cashier;
Each general cashier and main bank cashier to prepare a cashiers’ count sheet on each shift:
Recording the amount of the inventory in the window or bank;
Reconciling the total closing inventory with the total opening inventory; and
Including the signature of the:
Outgoing general or main bank cashier; and
Incoming general or main bank cashier;
At the end of the wagering day, the cashiers’ cage to forward a copy of each cashiers’ count sheet and related documentation to the accounting department for:
Agreement of opening and closing inventories; and
Comparison of forms or documents; and

No more than 48 hours after the discovery of an employee’s unresolved cage or count room overage or shortage of $500 or more, a sports wagering licensee shall submit a written report to the Commission describing:
The reason for the overage or shortage and corrective action taken or adjustment made; or
That a notice of investigation is ongoing and the written report will be submitted within the following 48 hours.
A sports wagering licensee may accept a negotiable instrument in the form of a check meeting the requirements of this regulation from a bettor to enable the bettor to take part in sports wagering.
A sports wagering licensee may accept a check only during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.10.17.02.
A sports wagering licensee may accept a personal check that is:
Made payable to the sports wagering licensee;
Drawn on a bank, savings and loan association, or credit union subject to federal or State banking regulation;
Drawn for a specific amount;
Currently dated, not postdated; and
Payable on demand.
Subject to the requirements of §E of this regulation, a sports wagering licensee may accept a check issued by:
A Sports wagering licensee;
The Agency; and
A person that:
Is an affiliate of the sports wagering licensee; and
Holds a valid sports wagering license in another jurisdiction.
A sports wagering licensee shall only accept a check under §D of this regulation which has been issued to an individual as:
Employment compensation; or
A payout in connection with:
Sports wagering activity;
Casino activity; or
Maryland lottery prizes.
A sports wagering licensee may not:
Except as provided under §C of this regulation, accept a check that is payable to an individual, including:
A Social Security check;
An unemployment insurance check;
A disability payment check; or
A public assistance check; or
Except for a check issued under §E of this regulation, accept from a bettor under this regulation a check or multiple checks which in the aggregate exceed $30,000 during a wagering day.
For a personal check equaling or exceeding $5,000, a sports wagering licensee shall confirm the availability of funds by:
Directly contacting the bank, savings and loan association, or credit union upon which the check is drawn;
Obtaining an authorization and guarantee of the check from a check verification and warranty service licensed as a contractor under COMAR 36.10.06.04; or
Alternate procedures addressing acceptance and verification of personal checks submitted in writing and approved by the Commission.
